bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Leatha Logan, February 6, 1942

div1.p: Hench is reluctant to share his Camp Lazear photo with Logan for her planned booklet since it is important to his own forthcoming book.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Leatha Logan, February 6, 1942
div1.opener:
February 6, 1942
Miss Leatha Logan
1505 West Nelson Street
Marion, Indiana
My dear Miss Logan:
div1.p:
I am indeed interested in your plans to prepare a booklet
on the life of the men who conquered yellow fever. There seems to be quite
a number of articles to be published on this subject. General Truby, who
was commanding officer in Cuba when Walter Reed was there, is writing his
autobiography. A lady in Washington is writing a book for children on the
life of Walter Reed. One of the volunteers has written up his story and
Walter Reed's daughter has collected some of her father's letters for
publication. I have been helping most of these people as I have spent
several years now looking up old records and documents, photographs, etc.,
visiting survivors and visiting Cuba on two occasions. I have collected
considerable unpublished data and the Mayo Clinic has authorized me to
publish a monograph on the subject. Looking back on my recent activities
I realize that I have given away a considerable amount of my material to
others and if I keep on doing so there will hardly be any value or ori-
ginality to my own monograph. I would appreciate, therefore, knowing
just what type of booklet you plan, how large a booklet it will be, where
it is going to be published, etc. I do want to be helpful and I should
be glad to let you have a photograph of the little Building No. 1 as we
discovered it, but you realize that our story of the discovery of this
building will be one of the really original parts of my own book and I
don't want to make the discovery of this little house so extensively known
that my own telling of it will be a story too late to interest anyone.
I shall be interested indeed to hear from you further.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
